## About me




## Qualitative coding 


- Tools
  - manual
  - non-dedicated software (MS Word, MS Excel)
  - __CAQDAS__ - Computer-assisted qualitative data analysis software
- Approaches
  - Codebook applied (e.g., content analysis)
  - Codebook built from material (e.g., grounded theory)
- Material
  - documents (various types/media)
    - e.g., newspaper articles
  - interview and focus group transcripts
  - field notes

<div style="color: red;">
_Coding is just one way to conduct qualitative research!_
</div>

## R advantages?

- We do not speak other languages
- As R is commonly used in the social sciences, having an application in R has the potential to bring qualitative and quantitative researchers together
- R is well equipped to run statistical evaluations on the backend of the app
- Many useful packages that we can rely/depend on
- `Shiny` approach makes it (relatively) easy to build UI and offload some (_important_) functionality to the browser


## What is reQual?

:::{.r-fit-text}
reQual is (yet another) FOSS application for qualitative research powered by R programming language
    - developed with reproducibility in mind 

> How can CAQDAS enhance reproducibility of qualitative research?

- basic coding of documents 
  - RQDA-inspired toolset
  - matching the features of more mature projects, such as QualCoder or proprietary tools, is not the top priority
-  basic requirement for reproducibility
   - FOSS & logs
- team collaboration 
  - ability to serve your own instance online with multiple-user projects, like Taguette
  - enhances reproducibility by identifying consensus in coding
  - accounting for the coders' background
<!---
> The uncritical adoption of a range of “technical fixes” (such as purposive sampling, grounded theory, multiple coding, triangulation, and respondent validation) does not, in itself, confer rigour. (Babour)
--> 
:::

## Can you use it?

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}
-   reQual is now a working prototype
-   tested for teaching qualitative methods at two Czech universities
<hr>

::: {.r-fit-text}
-   to teach basic coding for students `r fontawesome::fa("check", fill="green")`
-   to help develop the program (bug reports, feature requests) `r fontawesome::fa("check", fill="green")`
-   to conduct research `r fontawesome::fa("question", fill="red")` (it depends)
    - `r fontawesome::fa("plus", fill="green")` you are in full control of the data
    - `r fontawesome::fa("plus", fill="green")` necessary features are available
    - `r fontawesome::fa("minus", fill="red")` heavy development leads to frequent breaking changes `r fontawesome::fa("arrow-right", fill="red")` you may need to isolate your version from updates
:::

## Reproducibility & qualitative research

::: {.r-fit-text}
- is reproducibility a useful and productive concept for qualitative research?
  - the jury is still out
- even in computational and quantitative research, reproducibility is always an ideal, not a done deal

![](https://owncloud.cesnet.cz/remote.php/dav/public-files/d4m0svnAn2oLo5w/repro_spectrum.png){height="250px"}

- reQual is a tool to think and experiment with the principle of reproducibility in qualitative research

::: {.absolute bottom="30px" left="0"}
Peng, Roger D. 2011. “Reproducible Research in Computational Science.” Science 334(6060): 1226–27.
:::
